S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Specification of experimental machine
S5.T1.table:
OS Ubuntu 17.10
CPU Intel Core i5 7500 3.4GHz
DRAM 8GB
Storage SSD 480GB
references:
First, the behavior of the proposed on-device federated learning
approach is demonstrated by merging trained results from multiple edge
devices in Section 5.2.
Then, prediction results using the merged model are compared to
those produced by traditional 3-layer BP-NN (backpropagation based
neural network) and 5-layer BP-NN in terms of the loss values and
ROC-AUC (Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve - Area Under Curve)
scores in Section 5.3.
Those are also compared to a traditional BP-NN based
federated learning approach.
In addition, the proposed on-device federated learning is evaluated in
terms of the model merging latency in Section 5.4, and
it is compared to a conventional sequential training approach in
Section 5.5.
Table 1 shows specification of the experimental machine.

These latencies are measured on the experimental machine shown in
Table 1.

references:
A vector of 225 features from the car driving dataset, that of 561
features from the human activity dataset, and that of 784 features
from MNIST dataset are fed to
the neural-network based on-device learning algorithm
[2] for anomaly detection.
The numbers of input-layer nodes
and output-layer nodes are same in all the experiments.
The forget factor α𝛼\alpha is 1 (i.e., no forgetting).
The batch size k𝑘k is fixed to 1.
The number of training epochs E𝐸E is 1.
The number of anomaly detection instances is 2 [18].
These instances are denoted as Device-A and Device-B in our experiments.
The OS-ELM based anomaly detection with the proposed cooperative model
update is implemented with Python 3.6.4 and NumPy 1.14.1.
As a comparison with the proposed OS-ELM based anomaly detection,
a 3-layer BP-NN based autoencoder
and 5-layer BP-NN based deep autoencoder
(denoted as BP-NN3 and BP-NN5, respectively) are implemented
with TensorFlow v1.12.0 [24].
The hyperparameter settings in OS-ELM, BP-NN3, and BP-NN5 are
listed in Table 3222
Gh​i​d​d​e​nsubscript𝐺ℎ𝑖𝑑𝑑𝑒𝑛G_{hidden}: activation function applied to all the hidden layers.
Go​u​tsubscript𝐺𝑜𝑢𝑡G_{out}: activation function applied to the output layer.
p​(x)𝑝𝑥p(x): probability density function used for random initialization
of input weight 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} and bias vector 𝒃𝒃\bm{b} in OS-ELM.
N~isubscript~𝑁𝑖\tilde{N}_{i}: the number of nodes of the i𝑖ith hidden layer.
L𝐿L: loss function.
O𝑂O: optimization algorithm.
k𝑘k: batch size.
E𝐸E: the number of training epochs.
.
Here, 10-fold cross-validation for ROC-AUC criterion
is conducted to tune the hyperparameters with each dataset.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4: Training, prediction, and merging latencies [msec]
S5.T4.table:
Number of hidden-layer nodes N~=64~𝑁64\tilde{N}=64
Training latency Prediction latency Merging latency
OS-ELM 0.471 0.089 5.78
BP-NN3-FL 0.588 0.290 1.95×R1.95𝑅1.95\times R
Number of hidden-layer nodes N~=128~𝑁128\tilde{N}=128
Training latency Prediction latency Merging latency
OS-ELM 0.794 0.106 21.8
BP-NN3-FL 0.980 0.364 2.42×R2.42𝑅2.42\times R
references:
Table 4 shows the evaluation results in the cases of
N~=64~𝑁64\tilde{N}=64 and N~=128~𝑁128\tilde{N}=128.
The number of input features is 561.
The merging latency of OS-ELM is higher than those of training and prediction
latencies, and it depends on the number of hidden-layer nodes
because of the inverse operations of N~×N~~𝑁~𝑁\tilde{N}\times\tilde{N}
(size of matrix 𝑼𝑼\bm{U} is N~×N~~𝑁~𝑁\tilde{N}\times\tilde{N}).
Nevertheless, the merging latency is still modest.
Please note that the merging latency of BP-NN3-FL is required for
each communication round during a training phase, while the merging
process of our OS-ELM based federated learning approach is executed only once
(i.e., “one-shot”).
Thus, the proposed federated learning approach is light-weight
in terms of computation and communication costs.
